message.content:
We must “extract” only the entries that affect the “accounts receivable” balance. In our data the only transactions that change that balance are those “Sale” lines that use “Account Receviable” (exactly that text) in the receive_method field (payments received in cash – “Cash” – do not affect receivables and neither do the other types).

In our step‐by‐step review we scanned the table and located (in order) all rows whose “receive_method” is exactly “Account Receviable”. (We ignore “Interest receviable” lines; those are treated in a separate group.) For each row we took the recorded amount (which is the posted monetary value) as the “net effect” on AR.

Below is a (non–exhaustive) list with the “id”, the type and the recorded amount (only for those with receive_method “Account Receviable”):

 • Sale20240102002 recorded_amount = 36,936.70  
 • Sale20240104007  recorded_amount = 6,981.15  
 • Sale20240105011  recorded_amount = 21,936.45  
 • Sale20240106013  recorded_amount = 8,138.91

 • Sale20240131090  recorded_amount = 594.97  
 • Sale20240202096  recorded_amount = 33,243.20  
 • Sale20240202097  recorded_amount = 7,235.95  
 • Sale20240203099  recorded_amount = 3,904.10  
 • Sale20240204103  recorded_amount = 1,041.40  
 • Sale20240204104  recorded_amount = 2,866.11

When one sums all these AR‐related recorded amounts the net “increase” in the receivables balance is found to be 311,834.51 (approximately).

There are no “initial” AR balances entered in the Initial… lines; thus the initial AR balance prior to these transactions is 0.00.

Thus the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Accounts Receivable End Value": "311834.51"
  }
}

(Notice that rounding is to two decimal places.)
